channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Azar Castigates W.H.O. at Global Health Meeting
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China defends his country’s handling of the outbreak. Autoworkers return to plants in Michigan, and more states move toward reopening. Undocumented immigrants in California can begin applying for aid.

item.title: Immigration Agency That Issues Visas, Green Cards Struggles to Stay Afloat
item.description: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services has asked Congress for a lifeline amid the coronavirus pandemic that has caused applications to plummet and brought it to the brink of insolvency.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: A naturalization ceremony in 2019 administered by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services in Los Angeles.

item.title: One More Relationship Tested by the Pandemic: Siblings
item.description: For many brothers and sisters, the coronavirus and its limits on relationships outside the home have upended their dynamics.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, the Martínez siblings Joaquín, 16; Alizabeth, 8; J.J., 18; and Analeis, 11, playing outside their home in Saline, Mich.

item.title: As States Reopen, Governors Balance Existing Risks With New Ones
item.description: The costs of the coronavirus shutdown, economic and otherwise, have driven many people to the breaking point. But governors are increasingly worried about the costs of reopening, too.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: California is one of many states emerging from stay-at-home restrictions in gradual, regional steps. Beachgoers strolled in Laguna Beach, Calif. on May 9.

item.title: Thinking of Buying a Bike? Get Ready for a Very Long Wait
item.description: The United States is facing a shortage of bicycles as anxiety over public transportation and a desire to exercise has sent the demand surging.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

item.title: Climate Change Is Making Hurricanes Stronger, Researchers Find
item.description: An analysis of satellite imagery from the past four decades suggests that global warming has increased the chances of storms reaching Category 3 or higher.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:description: Hurricane Florence, seen from the International Space Station, in the Atlantic in September 2018.

item.title: Cuffing of Black Miami Doctor Was Justified, Review Finds
item.description: But a Police Department investigation found that a sergeant had violated department rules in other ways when he detained Dr. Armen Henderson outside his home last month.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Dr. Armen Henderson said he was loading his van with tents to take to homeless people in downtown Miami when he was detained by a police officer last month.

item.title: WeWork Wants a Rent Break. Its Customers Do, Too.
item.description: Some who rent space from the troubled company say it has not been generous with them even as it seeks concessions from building owners.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many professionals and businesses that use WeWork, including this Los Angeles location, have not been able to go to the office for weeks because of stay-at-home orders.

item.title: State Dept. Investigator Fired by Trump Had Examined Weapons Sales to Saudis and Emiratis
item.description: A Democratic House committee chairman said the investigation might have been “another reason” for the firing of the inspector general, Steve A. Linick.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The United States resumed weapons sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, which have waged war in Yemen, above.

item.title: The New Face of Restaurant Hospitality Wears a Mask
item.description: As dining rooms slowly reopen, owners are scrambling to reduce risks and reassure customers with an array of gear. Face coverings lead the way.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.media:credit: Peyton Fulford for The New York Times
item.media:description: The staff at Chops Lobster Bar in the Buckhead neighborhood of Atlanta preparing for a shift, in the facial uniform of the moment.

item.title: Sudan Must Pay Billions to Terrorism Victims, Supreme Court Rules
item.description: In a unanimous ruling, the court said a 2008 law allowing punitive damages applied retroactively to 1998 bombings in Kenya and Tanzania.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: A bombing at the United States Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, in 1998, as well as one in Tanzania the same year, killed hundreds and wounded thousands.

item.title: Michelle Obama and MTV to Host Virtual Prom Celebrations for High School Seniors
item.description: The event on May 22 would be the latest high school ritual that students were celebrating online because of social-distancing rules.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: “You guys are missing out on a lot of major milestones,” Ms. Obama said in the Zoom call on Friday. “It doesn’t seem fair.”

item.title: Barr Dismisses Trump’s Claim That Russia Inquiry Was an Obama Plot
item.description: The attorney general said that an investigation into the Russia inquiry was focusing on others, not the former president.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr noted there was a difference between abusing power and violating the law.

item.title: Coronavirus Contact Tracing Jobs Are on the Rise
item.description: Tens of thousands of people across the United States have applied for the job of cold-calling strangers who may have been exposed to Covid-19. Here’s what it’s like.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: Rebecca DeCarlo, a medical student, conducts a follow-up interview with a person who was identified by the Georgia Department of Public Health as having been exposed to the coronavirus.

item.title: F.B.I. Finds Links Between Pensacola Gunman and Al Qaeda
item.description: The gunman in December’s shooting, a Saudi cadet who had trained with the U.S. military, had been in contact with the terrorist group, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.media:credit: Kyle Grantham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Three sailors were killed in the mass shooting in December at a naval air station in Pensacola, Fla.

item.title: Three Poets on Marriage and Female Identity
item.description: A discussion of wives, husbands and the names we choose to go by.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:description: Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera in San Francisco circa 1930.

item.title: Israeli Settler Found Guilty of Murdering Palestinian Family in 2015 Arson
item.description: Amiram Ben-Uliel, 25, faces a life sentence for an ethnically motivated assault that was widely condemned as terrorism.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Amiram Ben-Uliel was convicted on Monday of guilty of murder, attempted murder, arson and conspiracy to commit an ethnically motivated crime.

item.title: Moderna Coronavirus Vaccine Trial Shows Promising Early Results
item.description: The company said its preliminary test in 8 healthy volunteers was safe. It is on an accelerated timetable to begin a larger human trial soon.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.media:description: Moderna headquarters in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: PG&E Says Wildfire Victims Back Settlement in Bankruptcy
item.description: The vote to accept a $13.5 billion deal will help the California utility resolve its bankruptcy in time to qualify for a state wildfire fund.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: PG&E is trying to resolve its bankruptcy by June 30 to qualify for a state fund that will help shield it from liability in future wildfires.

item.title: On Politics: The Next Round of Pandemic Relief
item.description: An opening offer is met with resistance. This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: How Virus Data Can Mislead
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: If Democrats Hold a Big Convention, Will Anybody Come?
item.description: The Times interviewed 59 delegates who will help nominate Joe Biden. Most said they don’t want to risk their own health, or the health of others, by attending a full-scale convention in Milwaukee.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: The Democratic National Convention is still scheduled to take place at the Fiserv Forum in Milwaukee in August.

item.title: Were the Supreme Court’s Phone Arguments a Success?
item.description: “I see so many flaws in it,” said Lyle Denniston, the dean emeritus of the Supreme Court press corps, who has attended more arguments than any other journalist.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lyle Denniston in 2017. He covered the Supreme Court for The Wall Street Journal, The Boston Globe and other news outlets for six decades.

item.title: Freed by Court Ruling, Republicans Step Up Effort to Patrol Voting
item.description: Officials seek to recruit 50,000 poll watchers and spend millions to fight voter fraud. Democrats say the real goal is to stop them from voting.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voter filled out her ballot in an early vote center in Merced, Calif., in March.

item.title: Passed By for Decades, Clarence Thomas Is a New Symbol of the Trump Era
item.description: He isn’t yet the pop culture star that Ruth Bader Ginsburg — “Notorious R.B.G.” to many — is. But his fans think he could be.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.category: Created Equal: Clarence Thomas in His Own Words (Movie)
item.media:description: Justice Clarence Thomas in February after delivering a keynote address at the dedication of Georgia's Nathan Deal Judicial Center.

item.title: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, will testify before the Senate Banking Committee on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus News: Live Global Tracker
item.description: The fund would amount to collective European debt to help the countries hit hardest by the virus. At a World Health Organization meeting, China offered to provide $2 billion to fight the pandemic.
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Emmanuel Macron of France announced that they will launch a joint European Union recovery initiative on Monday.

item.title: Fire Consumes Storefront in Harlem
item.description: The fire started at 7:30 p.m. in a furniture store on 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia

item.title: Inspector General’s Firing Puts Pompeo’s Use of Taxpayer Funds Under Scrutiny
item.description: Accusations of improperly using government resources have trailed the secretary of state, but President Trump’s move to fire the State Department inspector general has handed Democrats a new weapon.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has denied wrongdoing.

item.title: 2 Kansas City Officers Charged With Assaulting Transgender Woman
item.description: Prosecutors said the officers slammed Breona Hill to the sidewalk and kneed her in the face, torso and ribs in an episode that a passer-by captured on video.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
item.category: Brummett, Matthew G (Kansas City, Mo, Police Officer)
Prichard, Charles (Kansas City, Mo, Police Officer)

item.title: Canadian Snowbirds Jet Crashes During Tribute, Killing One
item.description: Another member of the military was injured, the authorities said. The jet crashed into a house in Kamloops, British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: Two pilots appeared to eject from a Canadian Air Force Snowbirds jet just before it crashed on Sunday.

item.title: S. David Freeman, 94, Tireless Advocate for Clean Energy, Dies
item.description: A folksy but forceful “Green Cowboy,” he helped shape energy policy in the White House and at local utilities for seven decades.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:description: S. David Freeman in 2001, when he was running the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. He helped develop the nation’s energy policies under several presidents.
